title: Does the human brain create its own reality? - Quora

response.answer_text: Q: Does the human brain create its own reality? Sort of. You have to realize that the human brain is locked in a dark box (the skull) and only senses the outside world through electrical signals, which are generated by biological sensors for sound, light, chemical combinations we call odors, pressure, temperature, touch or texture, and some other odd sensors like orientation (which helps you keep your balance), body positions, accelerations and so on. But it all gets to the brain via electrical cables we call nerves, and those are interpreted to create, in the brain, what we call a “model” of the environment and the self. This is usually composed of thousands of sub-models, which can also be composed of sub-models. In my view right now through the window, is my neighbor’s white pickup truck. that is one sub-model among two dozen trees and bushes, five lawns in various states of health, fences, doors, solar panels, chimneys, mailboxes, sidewalks, the street, birds foraging on my lawn, roses, potted herbs on my other neighbor’s lawn, etc. All of those are sub-models within my environment. I am not really seeing them, per se, my brain takes signals that trigger a model, composed of neurons, that represent, say a potted plant I happen to know is tarragon, and that model then emits electrical signals to other models that might be associated (with potted plants in general, or tarragon, or Allison, the owner of this potted tarragon.) Inside the brain there is no image! We feel like there is, because actual images of a potted plant excite the same neural models as an imagined image of a potted plant. What seem like images to us are feelings of neural net works firing. (And guess what, Allison just came out to water her potted plants!) Models are idealized versions of the things we see in reality. My model of a sparrow is no specific sparrow, but in a way an average of all the sparrows I have seen, an ideal sparrow, and then when I see a real sparrow, the brain will “subtract” the ideal sparrow from it and annotate the differences: This real sparrow is bigger than the ideal, it has fewer tail feathers, the differences from our ideal make it look less than ideally healthy. Psychologists have shown that this is how we perceive beauty and health as well: for males or females, if we (using computers ) take metrics for faces and “average” them all together, we will end up with a face that most people regard as more handsome/beautiful than the real faces. (They’ve done photo beauty contests to prove that.) This suggests that our mind perceives beauty as a kind of “flawlessness”: Our model of a female face is the average of all the female faces we have seen (which varies by our locale) and when we see other faces, what we notice are the differences between them and the ideal. The fewer differences, and the less the severity of the differences, the more beautiful we perceive the face as being. (For elements that cannot be averaged, like eye color, sometimes harmless rarity wins; pale blue or green are uncommon, and often considered more beautiful then the common brown. Red would be uncommon, but not harmless and therefore not beautiful: Our model of “red” associates with health problems, like infections, rashes and bloody injuries). It doesn’t just apply to faces, but to everything we model: Flowers, cars, whatever. A “flawless” car is clean, shiny, without scratches, dents or wear. So yes, we create our own reality in this sense. The brain takes clues from its millions of sensors, and tries to reconstruct the external reality internally using these idealized models, perhaps with exceptions. Our models are being updating throughout our life. But they are necessarily an inaccurate representation of the actual reality. Things will be missed, glossed over, you may not even SEE them in the sense that they were in sight but your brain was too busy to incorporate all the exceptions, especially if your attention was elsewhere. So what you remember is the idealized model with few or no difference tags on it; e.g. all you remember is there was a “car”. Color? Model? I don’t know, officer, a car. Not a truck. Not a motorcycle. You didn’t “forget”, you were too busy to ever know. We can see this with experiments in which people watch actors doing something, and then recall what they saw, and that differs from the tape. Magicians can be very adept at this sort of misdirection, so when the magicians Penn and Teller watch another magician, to defeat this tendency, Teller is watching the magician’s right hand, while Penn is watching their left. This attentional focus defeats the magician doing something with both hands simultaneously, like distracting with the right while they do something sneaky with their left. The reality created by the brain is an attempt to model the external reality, but because models are necessarily simplified versions of the external reality, idealizations tagged with notable exceptions, actual reality can be a lot different than our perceived reality. That can be especially true when it comes to qualities we infer and do not sense directly at all, like properties of personality or emotion, or quality in product, or the quality of food before you can smell or taste it (judged on sight, e.g. on TV or on a menu). Because the model of a meal that looks ideal will link to a model of taste that is ideal, but might come up short in that sensory department. (Happens to me with apples all the time!)

Q: “Does the human brain create its own reality?” It has no choice. The brain isn’t an amoeba rolling around in direct contact with the earth, nor can it pry back its skull to feel the wind and experience the sun and stars directly. Instead, it is wrapped in the protection of the skull, depending on incomplete senses to provide some understanding of the outside reality. We know how the senses work, at least to a first or second order, and we know how long it takes for a sensation in the foot or eye to reach its first stop in the brain. We know how long it takes a novel sensation to be processed before it becomes available to our cognition, and those times range from 100 milliseconds (foot) to over 500 milliseconds (eye). All of the traditional evidence suggests that a human being is some sort of automaton, receiving inputs from the external senses, using them to construct a unified picture that matches the world, using the picture to formulate actions, and instructing our muscles to make the actions happen. This is the input-process-output (IPO) model of the brain. While this has been the physical model of a human for thousands of years, philosophers have known for that same time span from simple observation that it doesn’t explain human behavior or experience. The earliest and perhaps clearest expression of this dilemma is Plato’s Allegory of the Cave, where he suggests that there is a “real” reality available if we will only step outside the cave. This conundrum has encouraged thinkers to create many explanations of our lived experience that can be consistent with our understanding of how the material of the body works. Most of them involve inventing a new substance, called variously the mind, soul, consciousness, etc., that is related to the brain somehow, but has a more direct connection with “real” reality. The fact that we humans, and all but the simplest animals, live life in real time requires an explanation. I believe that we have evolved to live in an incomplete internal reality in real time, rather than a complete, objectively true reality that lags the present moment by seconds. In other words, any animal that chose to live with the IPO brain architecture was eaten by an animal that accepted a lesser reality. I’ve written extensively about the limitations of the human senses. They are far from perfect, and I would characterize them only as “good enough”. The limitations of our senses lead inexorably to limitations of how we see the world. Our evolution allowed us to succeed as a species by disconnecting us from reality. The only reality we can experience is the one we create inside the skull. We must make the best of it.

Does the human brain create its own reality? The human brain perceives reality based on the things we have learned. Most of the things we have learned, are based on the perceptions of reality created by other people. People that lived in the past and people that are currently sharing their perceptions of reality. Realities are perceived through social interactions, the writing of philosophers, scientists, religious leaders, and from the various types of transmitted media. The things we have learned from other people’s perceptions of reality, has influence our perceptions of reality. Based on these influences the brain creates a version of reality. The word reality is a “reference” to a moment of perception. A perception that is experienced due to the “effects” of a sensory experience, or due to the “effects” generated when we access our “influential” memories. Our moment to moment realities, are moment to moment perceptions. Example: The perceived reality of a sensory experience is based on sensory memories that trigger the recognition of a stimulus. Creating a sensory perceived reality. This in turn triggers access to word associative memories and from them we create a language-based version of reality. Our word associative memories are the basis for how we typically perceive reality. Our thoughts are language-based creations of reality. The things we perceive are “representations” of our experiences. This has been pointed out many times in other Quora postings. Most people don’t know that what we perceive are “representations” of our experiences, and all of us that do know, still perceive our sensory experiences as word associatively triggered moments of reality. Knowing that our perceptions are only representations of sensory and language triggered mental events, does not change our perceptions of reality. “Does the brain create its own reality?” It does, but as you can see, the answer is a little complicated. Based on individual experiences we create our own realities. Example: Hitting your finger with a hammer, triggers the creation of a reality and the creation of an “influential” memory. A language-based description of the experience is a representation of the reality of the experience. When we access the memories of hitting our finger with a hammer, (sensory and language based) the “influential” aspect of the stored memory triggers the perception of the reality. Our language-based perceptions of reality have been influenced by the perceived realities of various people. People that are living and people that died centuries ago. I hope this answers your question. If you want to delve deeper into how our memories “influence” the creation of our “reality” then continue reading. Accessed memories influence our moment to moment perception of reality. Accessed memories trigger our emotions. Motivate us. Influence us to defend the realities that our beliefs represent and determine the strength of the realities we perceive. When we create a memory, it is assigned a memory encoding. The memory encoding is based on a stimulus and is translated into electrical impulses. The electrical impulses are represented on memory traces electro-chemically. This is accomplished by charging neurons and the assignment of neurotransmitters. One of the functions of neurotransmitters is to represent a memory’s importance level. Neurotransmitter represent the level of a memory’s stored valuation. A valuation that determines a memory’s “influence” when it is accessed. Memory valuations vary from low temporary levels of valuations, to levels of valuations based on repetitive experiences and valuations that are assigned due to survival and or emotionally triggered events. All memories receive a level of assigned valuations as they are created and stored. The perception of our moment to moment realities is the “effect” triggered by the influences of our accessed (valued) memories. Memories that represent sensory experiences (Reality) or language defined perceptions of reality. Example: If it looks like a cardboard box. Feels like a cardboard box and triggers access to visual, and tactile memories. Then a reality is perceived. The sensory memories trigger access to word associative meanings, and the triggered perception of a cardboard box. When we access memories that have been assigned emotional levels of valuations, the accessed memories trigger the emotions of the previous experiences. The emotions trigger the “effect” of a perceived reality. Emotions, such as joy, fear and even anxieties are “at the moment” triggered perceptions of reality. Many of our realities are based on memory valuations that have been corrupted by misinformation. When accessed, corrupted memory valuations trigger the creation of bogus realities.

As most others have said, YES. However, the reason it does so is one of limitations. Our brain is very slow by computer standards. Our memory capacity is also very limited. Accordingly, we have evolved to make a lot of assumptions. The world around us moves very quickly. We have to be able to make an internal map of the external world with very little information and react with very little time to think. Mostly our brain makes very quick guesses and even acts on them before we have time to even start to think about the situation. That is why a tree root can appear to be a snake and we jump back for fear of it before our conscious thinking process has even noticed the root at all. We may remember seeing the snake clearly, but magically it has turned into a root after we recover. This is perhaps the reason why we originally believed in magical creatures in the forest. This is why we can read books that provide little description and still give us the type of imagery normally seen in watching movies. We also come up with many “rules of thumb” based on very inaccurate assumptions of the world. We may not even be aware we have done this. We may unconsciously assume that all bearded men are evil because a couple of them in our life treated us badly. The “reality generator” in our brain is very important. It pieces together an image of the world around us from a few quick glances, smell, touch, and lots of filling from memory and our imagination. It keeps working at night, creating vivid dreams that seem real while we are having them. But it is the reason our memory of events is very poor and changes over time. Future AI will have to have a robust reality generator, but most likely it will not be nearly as good as ours. Rather, more accurate sensors, a huge memory capacity, and thousands of parallel processors, each specializing in a different kind of analysis, will generate far more real maps of the external world than ours in the same amount of time. Unlike humans whose short term memory starts to fade quickly to open up space for new sensations, sensory buffers in robots will store lots of data that can be analyzed later to produce a more accurate analysis of the world, potential threats, the identity of all people in view, chemical analysis, etc. Most robots will pause for a few seconds to complete a more accurate analysis before taking action, unlike more reckless humans. However, military robots will kill far more quickly and efficiently than anything portrayed in movies like Terminator.

I see it the way Mark explained; there is just the one reality (all that which is actual.) However, our sense (or perception) of it is merely a useful fiction. An experience that exists only in our own minds but with the fidelity necessary to survive. For example, the colors we experience are pure fictions even though a small fraction of them do correspond to wavelengths of light the majority are manufactured by our minds to interpret a mixture of those frequencies. Our internal model is finely tuned for efficiency. A very small fraction of your visual field can detect color (the rest only brightness) yet our brains hide that from us by making it seem like our entire visual field is registering color. Likewise for our blind spot which is also cleverly concealed. That aspect of our minds—blending prior knowledge with incoming sensory data—is what we experience as reality. The most noteworthy aspect of this process is that we’re ill-suited to be uncertain about practically anything. We’ve evolved a host of deeply ingrained prejudices (like the presumption of agency to explain the unexpected) that unconsciously fill in all the blanks. But there’s good news too. While we can’t directly experience reality we can deduce what is real. For starters, we can deduce that the universe must be an inviolately lawful place for pure mathematics to be capable of describing it with such astonishing accuracy. And that simple fact allows us to rely on a straightforward algorithm (the so-called scientific method) to eventually work out as much about the true nature of reality as it is possible to know. And even why what we experience is what it is, and how it got that way. So in a literal sense the answer is no. Brains are manufactured by reality—not the other way around. However, only our experience or perception of reality matters—can shape our behavior, affect us, and is what feels real to our cognition. And that “place” is a product of our brains. In that sense the answer is yes.

Does the human brain create its own reality? Reality is a hypothetical medium by which one individual (you) can interact with other (hypothetical) individuals. I would say: no. “Reality” is a euphemism there. As it appears in your question. Reality is not really the word. Let’s get real. It’s obvious that all you experience of reality is in your head! Same goes for me, just sub in “my head.” ‘Course. We know that. All sensory input streaming into conscious awareness. Building up in memory, stored experience. Whipped out into connection and relation, deducing and concluding. Spotting discrepancy and refining out error. Building up and improving a conceptual model of reality. All this is yes, in your head. However, let me just be sensible and observe: most of us perceive or accept that other individuals (perceived) are more than likely things like us. Not creations of our head. I mean, this is theoretically possible, but what’s more likely? That you created me? That you are the only one in existence, and all apparent others are your beloved figments? Or that other perceived beings are beings, much like us, existing in the same relation to each other: headspace shut-ins, each equally dependent from a shared reality. Moving and negotiating a perceived outer shared realm of physics by means of reflex, intellect and sense(s). Chiefly we navigate by assuming that reality is what’s outside one’s head. I mean yes, your head is in reality too. It’s part of reality. Yet if we think of it on the “shared reality” model, there really is almost no reality inside your head. Almost none. Compared to how sheer much reality is outside? What have you got in there? It’s a slow-cookin’ big noodle in a bioelectrochemical fizz broth! It’s a lump of wet jazz. It’s an amazing thing to be sure, and let’s not stunt it. But let’s not inflate it to cosmic proportions, either. Compared to the cosmos? There is no comparison. The reality’s out there, chum. I believe that’s accurate. “Reality” is an inadequate and inaccurate word for what’s in one’s head. “Conceptual model of reality, continuously updated by live sensory input,” sure. Perception! “Perception” is just the word for what’s in your head. What the human brain creates is not “its own reality.” It creates its own perception. Its own perceptual/conceptual matrix. “Based on” or “inspired by” reality, sure. Not “a reality.” A perception. Not “its own reality.” Its own dynamic senses-spiked conceptual model of reality.  However, if you or anyone speaks of “my reality” or “my own reality,” that’s totally okay. People in general know what you mean. You don’t mean you think reality is all in your head. You kind of mean the opposite. Be fair! To speak of “my reality” or “one’s own reality” isn’t grandiose at all, it’s humble. You mean you’re aware that in your head is where you keep your copy. You mean that you’re aware bias is the woodgrain of conscious awareness. Unavoidable and universal to humanity, but each one’s bias as it grows, is caught and throttled and refined away, is not caught and thrives unawares, directing us by distortion of perception in ways that induce noncorrespondence to reality - each individual’s bias is unique, and some bias (typically known bias) may even be good. You know that you are biased, that “your reality” (i.e. perception) is not a perfect overlap with reality. For one thing, some distortion and loss are entailed by limitation alone. By the fact that all this available content is being spot-sampled via an often inattentive awareness in one single point of you. Point of you. Yes, “point of you,” too, but more to the point: point of you. It means you’re aware of your own subjectivity. And that’s cool. In fact, I’d call it “pretty cool.” By saying “its own” or “my reality,” you’re pretty much copping to the fact you know your copy is NOT reality per se. It’s a much, much tinier and far greater (in some senses) (such as perhaps yours) personal picture. A funky slice - your own. It features random, superhuge zoom on things others probably wouldn’t notice or care about! It has an overall minuscule fidelity by comparison with the whole real deal. The hard copy. But nobody has that. Nobody has objectivity. It’s the fantasy viewpoint: the view with the viewer subtracted. No one has had or ever could come out upon such view. So yes, limited! Yes, biased - in favor or against, according to our bent, tendency, inclination. According above all to what we value. Yet a pretty nifty app, for all that. Continuously-updated live by streaming content. I mean, how much do we expect to fit in there? It’s not much bigger than a volleyball. I’d say we get a pretty good-sized land of make-believe and make-it-fit in there. Respectable feat for a relatively-puny creature of our instincts and drives, capacities and inclinations. In most cases, preferences as well. A perception of reality. That’s what the human brain creates. From scratch, since before birth. From available materials of sight, sound, scent, taste, touch and balance. From within the pull of gravity, and without appreciable let or hindrance once we bust loose all grabby and walky and talky. A perception that builds depth and resolution as it goes. Well, depending on the goer.

I think that this question is the wrong way around. The brain does not create its own reality. Our mental states reflect the reality that produces them. This is done by electrical signals from the sense organs being thoroughly processed by neurological brain structures, which are continuously improved by experience. We do not perceive things in terms of mental models or representations. We perceive objects in the external world, directly, by means of the sensory signals that objects give off, and our neurological processing of them (which is done automatically, extremely quickly and unconsciously). However, these systems can be fooled by sensory illusions. These help us to find out exactly how these systems work. With such illusions, we soon realise that direct perception does’t work, because we get contradictory, absurd or distorted results. So, we then unconsciously fall back on constructing mental models, to try to understand the illusion. Subjective experience is often objectively the case. For instance, when a lot of people observe the same event. And ‘‘this ‘mass objectivity’ is good evidence in favour of my hypothesis. Although the sensory experience is the same for nearly everyone, taking different view points into account, different people will almost certainly have different opinions and different emotional reactions to what they’ve experienced, and this could affect their account of it, even if they’re trying to be honest and truthful. There are many global, mental and emotional variables which could affect someone’s account. Eg bias, political persuasion, religious beliefs, opinions etc etc. Physical reality is a definite state of affairs, and our perceptions of them are generally an excellent reflection of that reality which gives rise to it. Furthermore, our various perceptions all agree with each, when experiencing a particular event. Which means that they are very sensitively integrated. This is no model. It is an accurate mental experience of our external world. Mental reality, based on brain malfunctions, rather than on objective experience, are very difficult to understand, diagnose and treat. All that we can say is that they are based on an interaction between past experience, which may include psychological trauma, genetic factors and present circumstances. If the illness was cased by trauma, then therapy can be very helpful.. If it’s genetically based, then only medication can help, and there are now excellent, clean meds that are now available.

Does the human brain create its own reality? Absolutely! I wouldn’t want anyone else to do it! In fact no one else can. Everything that you have done, thought about doing, along with how you compare that to what other people say, is an integral part of that. So, it seems that lots of beliefs are going to be considered delusional, because they are. That’s why they are beliefs, and beliefs are different than facts. You can be delusional in a group, and it is considered normal. There are many examples throughout the world, so I won’t mention them specifically. There is a profound difference, between delusions and psychosis. If someone has an account that sounds impossible to have occurred, doesn’t mean delusions or psychosis. Whatever your reality is, it’s created by your brain. Many parts of everyone’s reality are composed of shared delusions. To someone with psychosis, their hallucinations are reality during that time, and likely has an identifiable medical condition. It would affect their reality. What we really mean when we say reality, is that we probably don’t understand it ourselves. We do the best we can to interpret and integrate experiences, and to correlate them with others, further contributing to our reality. At that point confirmation bias becomes a significant factor. In order to keep a clean interface, or whatever other reasons, we will notice things that conform to our perceived reality. Depending on a variety of factors, confirmation bias can make a simple set of circumstances, flow into entirely new experiences. It’s an easy shoot from the hip response people can use to argue against lots of things, making reality a difficult property to define.

The brain is just a physical instrument for the mind. It is the mental planes from where ideas come and great ideas are inspired by the soul. When you talk about reality do you mean what we think and feel, say and do on a daily moment to moment basis? Because really that is just conditioning from past experience and from significant role models particularly from our youngest age. Generally our reality confirms our conditioning and vice versa.Psychologists largely agree that our view of ourselves and hence world view is set by the age of three.Some take the rest of their lives attempting to alter that self image. Some find confirmation only good or bad.Jesus taught “a man is as he thinks” but it hasn’t sunk in yet, the wider implications. “Energy follows thought”, which is why the great spiritual teachers all taught harmlessness of thought, or correct thought.Our world is filled with wrong thought, desire for war, greed, and complacency which causes starvation and other harm and all this has a direct affect on matter. Even the matter that forms weather and forms the planet itself.The main reason we can think like this is because we have been educated by the prevailing systems to believe we are separate from one another. It is a myth, the myth of separation.When we comprehend that there is no separation in Life we will stop doing terrible things to each other and an equilibrium will return to the natural world in return.Energy follows thought. Yes we can make our own personal reality to a degree and we can influence those around us to a degree. And we can lead loving lives helping each person we have contact with but world change will only come with change of world thought.I forget who said “change oneself to change the world”.A big part of the problem is our attachment to material planes, to money, profits, to power over others and to this end the Buddha gave us The Four Noble Truths. Our reality changes when we lose our attachment to the material levels. As Jesus taught, we will be in the world but not of it.Reality, no one persons reality is separate from anyone elses.

That can be subjective. As the human brain can “deny reality” by refusing to acknowledge or accept it for a variety of reasons (some cannot face the truth and accept facts). So their mind will perceive “reality” another way that they can cope with or which fits with their belief system or agenda. In this regard the human mind is creating its own perception of reality which may become distorted. Where others through acceptance of reality, have a sounder perception of it, that the mind processes but does not create; - and are more likely to be able to deal with it, make logical judgments and find solutions. The human brain can be trained to create its own reality through one’s “belief system” or through “limited knowledge and experience”. For example some who have had bad experiences may believe and define the reality of the world/life as “an unsafe, cruel and a bad place or state of being”. Where others have the insight that there is good also and view the real reality of life as a shade of grey. Reality depends on how the mind perceives things and its capacity to “comprehend reality”. Whether insight is present that “can see and grasp” the truth of any matter being the reality. Or perceives a “distorted version” of it either willingly (to suit/denial), or through faulty thinking and/or limited knowledge and life experience. Some will be more “in-tune”with reality than others as they “open up their minds to it” through acceptance, thus acquiring more knowledge and a deeper insight of reality. There are less psychological barriers which produces a “clearer perception”, freeing the mind up to process a sounder grip of reality. While with some through either denial of reality, disease/mental illness, faulty thinking/mindset, tunnel vision/grandiose pride and lack of insight - results with the mind creating and processing a reality based on “misguided or distorted perception” - that if severe enough the mind can potentially lose “touch with reality becoming delusional”.

The human brain creates our individual perception of reality. Reality exists whether we perceive it or not. Evolution has, over millions of years, finely tuned our senses and perceptions to experience the natural world quite accurately…. Else we would not have survived. We are capable of detecting the very minor visual differences between ripe and unripe fruit, or fruit with perhaps diseases…. We can tell if meat we’ve cooked has “gone off” and is dangerous to eat…. We can detect patterns and movement very acutely. Other animals can do these things better than we in many cases… A dog has a sense of smell thousands of times more acute than our own, for instance. But the meat is still rotting, whether we must hold it to our nose to sniff, or if a dog can detect this from 50 yards away. Note that our individual perceptions differ from each other….But only slightly. If I ask 100 people to describe this reddish hardened clay object I’m holding, they would likely all say “that’s a brick”. Not, “that’s a cucumber” or “that’s a turtle”. If I hold up a red rose, again the vast majority of people would say that it’s color was “red”. (Even though roses come in other colors) The only exception would be the small percentage of the population who are having some degree of “color-blindness”. We may not individually perceive the “exact” same shade of red, but it would be quite close. Color, after all, is dependent on the particular frequency of visible light that’s reflected from a given object. The frequency is exactly the same, in the case of our rose, so very likely our individual visual cortexes see it pretty much the same way.

Yes and no. Yes in two ways (maybe more) — 1. Optical illusions. You ordinarily look at something, the brain interprets it, and gives you an image.  However, the interpretation may be an incorrect representation of the actual thing you’re looking at in some cases.  He owns a gun... Or is that just a drawing? /  A wine cup. /  The cat’s going up the stairs, not down. / 2. Dreams. This is another way the brain creates its own reality. We’ve all had bizarre dreams which we had no control over. It seems the brain just makes up whatever images or places or faces it wants to in these cases.  / On the flipside, no, the human brain does not create its own reality strictly speaking. Reality is totally independent of what the brain perceives or prefers. Gravity for example will take effect whether we like it or not. That being said, the Bible does mention that we have the ability to change reality by faith. In essence creating our own reality. Peter for example created his own reality when he walked upon the sea. At that point he didn’t care too much for the phenomenon called gravity. His brain however began to pay attention to the turbulent winds and waves, which in turn made him become afraid, and thus reverted him back to the ordinary default reality as he began to sink. So the brain creates its own reality, and the brain does not create its own reality.  “O ye of little faith…” Thanks for asking.

There are different perspectives from which this can be approached, but increasingly these all lead to the same answer - yes - but each with a different implication. (1) From the current scientific paradigm of objective realism (the assumptions that the universe is physically out “there” (real) and open to independent scrutiny (objective) - both of which is being challenged by quantum physics) the simple answer is yes. Sensory inputs are turned into biochemical cascades in the brain. It is claimed that these are then turned into mental models which we experience as sensory objects. Therefore, the world you perceive with your senses right now is, according to science, being created by your brain. Because of its foundational assumptions (objective realism), science believes that we can, nevertheless, deduce the nature of the (assumed) reality out there. This, however, is beginning to unravel as quantum physics challenges both objectivity and realism. It should also be noted that this perspective leads to the hard problem of consciousness, which is insurmountable. In this perspective the brain is considered real, and the perceptions are subjective secondary effects. (2) From deep Darwinism, experience did not evolve to represent reality, but only to show us useful representations that enable us to best survive. The assumption that the fittest mental representation would be the most accurate has been shown to be wrong. From this perspective, all we ever experience is a selected “icon” which has no inherent need to represent truth. Cats, tables, Colours, space, time… everything… is just a functional interface for survival like the interface of your computer. The icons on your computer desktop “work” but tell you nothing about the functioning of the reality (electrons in silicon) that is behind it. Likewise the world we see, study and measure can tell us nothing of the reality behind it. In this perspective the reality “out there” is the forever unknowable Darwinian “Selector”. Experience as a whole is the selected (created) reality, but not created by the brain as we usually think of it, as that is itself merely another icon (selected representation), and as such has no intrinsic reality. The unknowable selector behind it all is the real source of reality. (3) From self-knowledge. If you engage in correct self-observation you can arrive at a direct perception of the method by which you create your reality. To get past this question I have to explain a logical error which appears everywhere in scientific circles, and which scientists are happy to promote … it flatters them hugely. The Fallacy of Prediction: When once scientist manages, by hard research to learn how to predict a phenomenon (like light, gravity, magnetism, radiation etc.) he/she goes public and the public telling that he/she can predict something previously unpredictable and the public is hugely impressed: Einstein, Curie, Avogadro, Volta, Newton, Galileo etc. then become famous, are lionized, and it will inevitably be said of them that they discovered how nature works because they figured out how to predict previously mysterious events and if they can do that then they are geniuses and they understand that particular bit of nature. It’s rubbish, all they can do is predict, they can do that without understanding gravity, radiation or the true nature of light. Tons of evidence for this phenomenon. That’s the fallacy of prediction: all of use assume that the woman or man who discovers the predictive formulas must understand what they predict. The next thing you find is that people (the whole culture) will stop worrying about the now predictable events and a new mystery takes the attention of the research community, and the public drives them on so that they and the public will come to understand “our World”. teachers will explain it all, roughly, to all the kids and they will grow up ‘knowing ‘why’ there is gravity, why light is the maximum speed attainable, why electricity can flow down a solid copper wire (it doesn’t) as if it were a pipe, etc. In short, they come to believe that a mystery has been solved, an explanation is now available to them. Well, that be the myth. Science predicts, yes, but it does not explain. Newton was asked soon after he became famous for having got the first general equations for gravitation, he was asked “what then is gravity” he replied immediately that he had not the slightest idea, he only knew its effects. He was credited with knowing what gravity was and he stubbornly denied it. He was a mighty good logician! And an honest man. Now, that’s what’s going to happen with the brain. We will study it carefully, scientifically, until we can predict its effect on the human body its in. That will happen. But we will not get to understand how the brain discovers reality, how it sees colour a thousand miles away etc., . So that’s the answer: the brain research reaches the public and the prediction come rattling in, they, us, will feel that the mysteries of the brain, and so of the mind, have been resolved. Look, even Newton did not claim to understand gravity! The discoverers of electricity remained baffled! We can learn to predict but explanations elude us. What you are asking for is an explanation and, guaranteed, neither you nor me will ever get one. And that’s philosophy.

Scientifically speaking, I would say that the brain creates its own simulation derived from a series of sensory input from reality. Think of a can laying on the ground. You say you see a rectangle because you see the can from the side. Neither of you know that it is a can, so the natural conclusion people come to is that THEIR version of reality is true which makes all other versions false. The truth is, more often than not, different based on the perspective chosen. In the case of the can, the truth is a combination of the truths from both perspectives, and possibly more. Does the human brain create its own reality? Reality = Nature/Universe + Brain/Mind Reality by definition is the individual and subjective experience of the external and the internal worlds. For creatures having brains, the reality cannot be separated from their mind or brain*. But in this observation about reality, care must be taken NOT to confuse the reality with the nature or universe. *(there are living forms without brains like trees, amoebas, sponges who also must be sensing and experiencing some reality of their vicinity or more — for surviving at least.) The nature and universe are existing by their own regardless of experiencing them in any brain or mind. Reality is the interaction of the nature/universe with brain/mind. Nature exists outside brain/mind. Reality exists only inside living brain/mind. Hence a stone or a dead person aren’t considered as having any reality of their own, because they are not supposed to have any living mind. Reality requires both the brain/mind and the universe. So the bottom-line answer to your question is, YES. But the reality the brain creates is dependent on the external and internal worlds.

On a multitude of levels, yes. We interpret information gathered through a vast array of senses, the centrally recognized being sight, taste, touch, smell and hearing. These senses among others are only able to perceive a small fraction of their total energetic spectrums. For example, we only perceive a combination of shades and primary colours, we can see less than 1% of the visible light spectrum, we can hear less than 1% of the sound spectrum, etc. We filter the small fraction of information we receive through the brain, which is inherently bias depending on the vocabulary that we use to interpret the world. So not only are we interpreting a small fraction of reality, but we also define reality through our own unique vocabulary or perspective. And in many cases, there are gaps in our interpretations, so we will fill those gaps (visual, auditory, olfactory, somatic, gustatory, etc.) in order to create a fluid experience. And that's only accounting for the things we actually experience. Most of our world now with globally accessible and constantly active social media and information sharing can lead us to fill in gaps with mostly unfounded projections and assumptions. So it is VERY important to trust but verify. Seek to understand reality at a fundamental level, and build models from there.

In a sense, the brain does create its own reality, a virtual reality that is created by nonconscious functions processing stimuli utilizing expectations based on prior experiences. Invariable, the virtual reality will not accurately represent actual reality for several reasons. Insufficient experience limits the ability to relate all of the interrelated aspects of one’s sensory experience relative to each other and to the individual. Sensory experience conflicting with expectations create perturbations that initially are resolved by denying the validity of the experience or selectively accepting parts, often by distorting them, that support their expectation. Congruency between virtual and actual realities improves with one’s willingness to consider their expectations can be inaccurate and when one’s is willing to suspend disbelief and allow the novelness of their sensory experience to possibly be correct (potentially expanding consciousness).

Our sensory organs roughly share a similar range of sensitivity. There is lot of variance. Loss of hearing, color blindness, visual acuity problems, differences in olfaction, etc—all these things feed into what we perceive. Genetics have a role. In many Mexican dishes cilantro is a common spice. Most people think it tastes great. Given my genetics, it tastes like soap! Training in cooking and tasting of beers, wines, etc, also have an impact. Age related decrements impact us—-while children may taste and smell things much more acutely. Culture also defines what we are seeing, smelling, tasting to a goodly degree. All these things add together producing common, but individual experiences of the world. We also have not mentioned how attitudes, beliefs, prejudices, etc. shape what we think we are seeing, hearing, etc. These not only impact how we sense things, but how we put together and interpret what we are sensing. So—yes our brains produce their own version of reality—but with some shared aspects. Stay well. Stay safe.

We know entangled particles can interact with each other, instantly even if they're galaxies away, far faster than light speed. It was tested on a satellite at the distance of 1,200 miles. We know that a photon somehow knows if we will observe/measure its state it changes from wave to particle behavior. Oh, and it knows even if it started its voyage thousands of light years away before the observer was even born. We also know an atom can be transposed in two realities until measured. It can have two temperatures and spins at the same time. So how come a human mind just knowing about it forces it to choose a state? You could train a monkey to watch the results and color code them so they could tell you if the light made an interference pattern. They would give you the same result, even if you did the experiment a million times. No interference. But we dont know if the monkey forced the collapse or if the collapse happened because before it departed the light already knows the monkey will impart that knowledge to a human. If you filmed it and never watched the film, the interference pattern would be on the film, because it knows you will never watch it… It doesn't make any sense. Yet we know it happens. It has been tested millions of times. The experiment is the double slit and I cite wheeler's delayed version for the part about it knowing before you are born. So while I don't speak in absolutes, we can say, with confidence, that the interaction between the human mind (and possibly other mammals) and the environment is far from understood.

To a large extent, it has to. Everything we think we know is based on internal models, shared among many — but still only models. The theological premise about Heaven being a place of light is largely influenced by the experiences of folks having undergone near-death experiences. The brain, when in the early stages of death undergoes hypoxia (oxygen deprivation), which causes those regions which have the highest oxygen dependency to experience the earliest effects. For most higher-order chordates, that is the frontal lobes. Not only are the frontal lobes used extensively in mapping memory into a personal timeline, but ever since our very early Cambrian ancestors these portions of the brain evolved to become sensitive first to heat, and ultimately to light — eventually becoming our eyes. It shouldn’t surprise us therefore that those experiencing hypoxia would have “flash-backs” to earlier memories, and to experience a growing sense of white light as our visual centers start to degrade. The latter is due to the inability of our visual cortex to distinguish shapes, boundaries or colors during oxygen depravation. In essence, our visual cortex “rewinds” to it’s earliest evolutionary role, namely allowing our bottom-feeding marine ancestors to detect sunlight (and presumably warmth) overhead. I’m sure there are many other “brain model” behaviors I’ve omitted.

Yes and no. Yes, perception and decision making (conscious and nonconscious) depend on neurons that are typically several neurons down the chain from sensory inputs. The sensory input data is compressed through dimensional transformations and perception is then filled in with implicit inferences about what the brain thinks it's seeing. Furthermore, due to internal biological dysregulation, like in schizophrenia or sleep deprivation, perceived stimuli that don't actually exist can be created by the brain. No. The brain is in a sense physically entangled with the environment. Our neural networks are typically oriented towards things that actually happen. Therefore, although perception is an internally generated entity, it is almost always tied to real things.

Well, yes. But there are some caveats. The human brain receives lots and lots of information, through the sensors of the human body, and by means of that torrent of information, builds up a picture, a simulacrum, of what the real physical world is like, out there. This is a reality, which usually matches the actual reality out there in the physical world. But occasionally, the brain goes nutso, and regardless of the information coming in from the sensors, develops an entirely different view of the world. It is wrong, in a whole bunch of different ways. But it is in this way that the brain creates its reality, because in this (rare) case it believes that the world is a wholly different thing than all the rest of us perceive and believe. So yes, the brain creates its reality, but sometimes that “reality” is wrong.

Not just humans; all animals with brains make internal maps of external conditions - physical reality - and use those internal maps to navigate the physical - and social - terrains. Humans have an extra feature; we have language, not just symbolic acoustical communication, but real language, with sarcasm, double meaning, metaphors, humor, high flying concepts, etc. Language evolved to help us navigate the social terrain. In order for us to survive, we had to learn how to cooperate, communicate, and follow a leader, which establishes a social hierarchy that requires complex symbolic communication to implement. Now, the word “reality” only means, it exists. So, what exists outside of our minds is a shared, universal reality, and a tiny bit of that shared, universal reality manages to make its way into our minds via sensory impressions, at which point our minds interpret the meaning of those signals, thereby setting up a non-shared, non-universal, subjective realm inside our heads, and we call that “reality”. In our attempt to share this subjective realm in our heads, language emerged. That is where the “person” inside that head lives, in the linguistic map of reality. If you turn your attention inward, you may be able to “hear” the continuous internal monologue that is the basis for your own personal sense of what is real.

I start with the physicist Niels Bohr: “Physics is to be regarded not so much as the study of something given a priori, but rather as the development of methods for ordering and surveying human experience.” Consider that we perceive almost no electromagnetic radiation, a small fraction of light, and a small fraction of sound. There is much in the world we cannot perceive at all. Add to this the problem of scale. Giant galaxies look like points of light, if we can see them at all. Molecules and atoms are entirely imperceptible. Thus, what we think we “know” about the world is, on the face of it, vastly incomplete. For much of what we do, none of this matters, and we go about our lives blissfully unaware of both our limits and our misperceptions. In other words, the world is not as we think it is. If that is true, then we do, indeed, create our own reality.

It creates reality full stop, i.e. there is no “objective” reality, only the reality the brain experiences: you can’t escape it. At best you can compare with others’ brains’ claims to create a composite reality to work with (the scientific method). E.g. your brain syncs the signal from your toe and eyebrow so your brain pretends they arrive at your brain at the same moment despite the additional time it takes for signals to travel from your toes. Your brain “fills in” the gap in your vision caused by your two eyes being a few inches apart and the optic nerve blind spot. As you know “color” is your brain’s imposition of labels to the sensation of the electromagnetic spectrum within the bounds of what humans can experience. Experience is mediated through old memories, and memory is not a recording but a constant re-interpretation of whatever interpretation your brain has had. There are hundreds of examples. “Objective reality” is our construct to make us feel better.

The brain certainly creates our realities. After all, our experience is far more than the various inputs that the brain receives. Consider an example from color perception research: our eyes can’t actually detect color outside of a few degrees of our focal point. You may think that you seek color in your peripheral vision, but you don’t. You can’t. Rather, you’re either sacading your focus to the periphery momentarily or your brain is filling in the color based on what colors it expects to see there.
